title: How to Measure Coffee Scoops for the Perfect Brew

steps.title: Use 1 scoop of coffee grounds per cup you’re brewing.
steps.content: Use 1 scoop of coffee grounds per cup you’re brewing. Most coffee scoops hold 2 tablespoons (10.6 grams) of grounds when they’re leveled. To make the most flavorful coffee , add a scoop of grounds for every 6 fl oz (180 ml) cup of coffee you’re brewing. [1] X Research source For a drip coffee maker, use the following ratios: 1 cup of coffee = 1 scoop (2 tbsp) of grounds, & 6 fl oz (180 ml) water 2 cups of coffee = 2 scoops (4 tbsp) of grounds, & 12 fl oz (350 ml) water 4 cups of coffee = 4 scoops (8 tbsp) of grounds, & 24 fl oz (710 ml) water 6 cups of coffee = 6 scoops (12 tbsp) of grounds, & 36 fl oz (1,100 ml) water 8 cups of coffee = 8 scoops (16 tbsp) of grounds, & 48 fl oz (1,400 ml) water 10 cups of coffee = 10 scoops (20 tbsp) of grounds, & 60 fl oz (1,800 ml) water 12 cups of coffee = 12 scoops (24 tbsp) of grounds, & 72 fl oz (2,100 ml) water

steps.title: Aim for a 1:15 or 1:18 ratio of coffee grounds to water.
steps.content: Aim for a 1:15 or 1:18 ratio of coffee grounds to water. When you measure coffee by weight, you can get more precise with your measurements. Coffee-to-water ratios are normally in the metric system, so for every 1 gram of coffee grounds you use, use around 15 or 18 milliliters of water. [2] X Research source For example, if you want to make a single cup of coffee for a 300 mL mug, then use 20 grams of coffee grounds. [3] X Research source Using a 1:15 ratio gives your coffee a stronger and richer flavor that’s more acidic because you’re using less water. When you use a 1:18 ratio, expect a more mellow, less acidic flavor from your cup of coffee.

steps.title: Use about 4 tablespoons (10.6 g) of coffee beans per cup.
steps.content: Use about 4 tablespoons (10.6 g) of coffee beans per cup. That’s around 75-80 individual coffee beans to make a delicious 6 fl oz (180 ml) cup of coffee. After you grind the beans , you’ll have about 2 tablespoons of grounds to brew. [4] X Research source Add 2 tablespoons (5.3 g) of coffee beans for every additional cup after the first one.

steps.title: How many scoops of coffee do you use in a French press?
steps.content: How many scoops of coffee do you use in a French press? Use 1 scoop, or 2 tablespoons (10.6 g), of coffee grounds for every 8 fl oz (240 ml) serving of coffee. When you brew with a French press , a 1:15 or 1:17 ratio makes the perfect coffee. [5] X Research source Use coarse coffee grounds that are about the size of breadcrumbs to make the most delicious cup of coffee. Have a different opinion? Share your thoughts on wikiHow's "So what's the right way to make French press coffee?" forum page.

steps.title: How many scoops of coffee do you use for pour-over?
steps.content: How many scoops of coffee do you use for pour-over? Use 1 scoop that’s 2 tablespoons (10.6 g) for each cup of coffee you’re brewing. For a precisely ratioed cup of pour-over coffee , use a 1:16 ratio of coffee grounds to water. [6] X Research source Use medium or coarse coffee grounds to help extract the most flavor from them.

steps.title: How many scoops of coffee do you use for cold brew?
steps.content: How many scoops of coffee do you use for cold brew? A single scoop works if you’re making one serving, but it varies on how strong you want to make your coffee. Try a 1:15 ratio of coffee to water for cold brew that’s ready to drink right away, or use a 1:5 ratio to make a coffee concentrate that you mix with water before serving. [7] X Research source

steps.title: How many scoops are in a package of ground coffee?
steps.content: How many scoops are in a package of ground coffee? In a standard 12 oz (340 g) bag, there are about 64 tablespoons of coffee grounds. If you’re using a normal coffee scoop, you’ll get about 20-30 scoops from the bag. Some coffee grounds and beans vary in weight depending on where they were grown and how they were processed, so your number of scoops may vary.
